storyboard
b

Horizontally in Container
c

inline_content.Text: Select your button (or whatever view you want to center) on the
storyboard
. Then click the align button on the bottom right. Select
Horizontally in Container
and
Vertically in Container
. Click “Add 2 Constraints”.

title: If it wasn’t perfectly centered already, you may need to do one more thing. Click the “Update Frames” button that is two to the left of the “Embed In Stack” button on the bottom bar.

inline_content.Text: If it wasn’t perfectly centered already, you may need to do one more thing. Click the “Update Frames” button that is two to the left of the “Embed In Stack” button on the bottom bar.

title: You can also “update frames as necessary” by pressing together ⌘ + ⌥ + = (Command + Option and equals) after selecting the view, this might save some time.

inline_content.Text: You can also “update frames as necessary” by pressing together ⌘ + ⌥ + = (Command + Option and equals) after selecting the view, this might save some time.

title: Now when you run your app it should be centered, no matter what device size you are using.

inline_content.Text: Now when you run your app it should be centered, no matter what device size you are using.

title: Another way to center views using Interface Builder is by control-click-dragging. Say you want to center a
UILabel
c
in a view. Open the
Document Outline
c
in your storyboard by clicking the sidebar button at the bottom left. Click and drag from the label to the view while holding ctrl (control), and a blue line should appear:

inline_content.Text: Another way to center views using Interface Builder is by control-click-dragging. Say you want to center a
UILabel
in a view. Open the
Document Outline
in your storyboard by clicking the sidebar button at the bottom left. Click and drag from the label to the view while holding ctrl (control), and a blue line should appear:

title: Upon release, a menu of constraint options will appear:

inline_content.Text: Upon release, a menu of constraint options will appear:

title: Select “Center Horizontally in Container” and “Center Vertically in Container”. Update frames as necessary, and voila! A centered label.

inline_content.Text: Select “Center Horizontally in Container” and “Center Vertically in Container”. Update frames as necessary, and voila! A centered label.

title: Alternatively, you can add the constraints programmatically. Create the constraints and add them to the desired UI elements and views as the following example describes, where we create a button and align it in the center, horizontally and vertically to its superview:

inline_content.Text: Alternatively, you can add the constraints programmatically. Create the constraints and add them to the desired UI elements and views as the following example describes, where we create a button and align it in the center, horizontally and vertically to its superview:
Objective-C
Swift

title:
override func viewDidLoad() 
{
    super.viewDidLoad()
    let yourButton: UIButton = UIButton(frame: CGRect(x: 0, y: 0, width: 100, height: 18))
    yourButton.setTitle("Button", forState: .Normal)

    let centerVertically = NSLayoutConstraint(item: yourButton,
                                   attribute: .CenterX,
                                   relatedBy: .Equal,
                                      toItem: view,
                                   attribute: .CenterX,
                                  multiplier: 1.0,
                                    constant: 0.0)
    let centerHorizontally = NSLayoutConstraint(item: yourButton,
                                   attribute: .CenterY,
                                   relatedBy: .Equal,
                                      toItem: view,
                                   attribute: .CenterY,
                                  multiplier: 1.0,
                                    constant: 0.0)
    NSLayoutConstraint.activateConstraints([centerVertically, centerHorizontally])
}

content_resolved.code:
override func viewDidLoad() 
{
    super.viewDidLoad()
    let yourButton: UIButton = UIButton(frame: CGRect(x: 0, y: 0, width: 100, height: 18))
    yourButton.setTitle("Button", forState: .Normal)

    let centerVertically = NSLayoutConstraint(item: yourButton,
                                   attribute: .CenterX,
                                   relatedBy: .Equal,
                                      toItem: view,
                                   attribute: .CenterX,
                                  multiplier: 1.0,
                                    constant: 0.0)
    let centerHorizontally = NSLayoutConstraint(item: yourButton,
                                   attribute: .CenterY,
                                   relatedBy: .Equal,
                                      toItem: view,
                                   attribute: .CenterY,
                                  multiplier: 1.0,
                                    constant: 0.0)
    NSLayoutConstraint.activateConstraints([centerVertically, centerHorizontally])
}
